ygData.subject: RE: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data

------=_NextPart_000_00BB_01CD12A2.717AD650
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Not sure if I understand what you are trying to say Barry. JSON-LD is
exactly that, a serialization format for labeled directed graphs.

 

 

 

From: Barry Norton [mailto:barrynorton@...] 
Sent: Wednesday, April 04, 2012 8:26 PM
To: Markus Lanthaler
Cc: rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] REST vs. Linked Data

 

 

On Wed, Apr 4, 2012 at 1:16 PM, Markus Lanthaler <markus.lanthaler@...>
wrote:

We went even so far to formally

define what define Linked Data is in the context of JSON-LD [2].

 

 

Careful, the next stumbling block, once people run out of steam on NIR/IR,
is serialisation.

 

Before anyone should give a damn about serialising IRs, and publishing NIRs,
you have to grok that what RDF actually is is a directed graph model, just
like the web, where relationships are disambiguated with URI-identified,
reusable properties.

 

Therefore that descriptions are uniformly made with these properties, in RDF
triples (specifying which property relates which resource to which other
resource), not spread across centralised semi-standardised link relations
and non-reused ambiguous relations in tree-like data models (JSON, XML,
etc.)

 

That's where the discussion should surely focus, not on range14 and
serialisation. These are side issues.

 

Barry


------=_NextPart_000_00BB_01CD12A2.717AD650
